Data package¶

The Data module provides utilities for managing project data. It includes functions for generating geometries, meshes, datasets, and deleting data folders.

data.dataset¶

data.dataset._reset_results(data_folder='test')[source]¶

Description

Empty the results folder by removing all files inside it.

Parameters:

data_folder (str) – Path to the data folder.

Return type:

None

data.dataset.generate_datasets(data_folder='test', empty_results_folder=True)[source]¶

Description

Generate datasets by processing all mesh files in parallel and saving the results.

Parameters:

  • data_folder (str) – path to the data folder.

  • empty_results_folder (bool) – Whether to empty the results folder before generating new datasets.

Raises:

FileNotFoundError – If the mesh folder does not exist.

Return type:

None

data.delete¶

Description

This script provides a simple utility to delete a folder. Part of the ‘data’ module as a helper.

Example of usage:

python -m data.delete --folder <data_folder_path>
data.delete.main()[source]¶

data.fom¶

data.fom._compute_boundary_normals_and_midpoints(domain, boundary_facets)[source]¶

Description

Compute boundary normals and midpoints for the facets of the upper plate (tags 10 and 11).

Parameters:

  • domain – The computational domain containing mesh information.

  • boundary_facets (ndarray) – The boundary facets associated with the domain.

Return type:

tuple[ndarray, ndarray]

Returns:

  • normals (np.ndarray) – Normal vectors at the boundary facets.

  • midpoints (np.ndarray) – Midpoints of the boundary facets.

data.fom._get_domain_from_mesh(mesh_path)[source]¶

Description

Read the mesh from the .msh file and return the computational domain.

Parameters:

mesh_path (str) – Path to the mesh file.

Returns:

  • domain (fem.Domain) – The computational domain containing mesh information.

data.fom.fom(mesh, bc_lower_plate=1.0, bc_upper_plate=0.0)[source]¶

Description

Full order model that solves the PDE with given boundary conditions and computes the solutions and its gradient.

Parameters:

  • mesh (str) – Path to the mesh file.

  • bc_lower_plate (float) – Dirichlet BC value for the lower plate.

  • bc_upper_plate (float) – Dirichlet BC value for the upper plate.

Return type:

tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray, ndarray, ndarray, ndarray, ndarray, ndarray, ndarray]

Returns:

  • x (np.ndarray) – x coordinates of all mesh nodes.

  • y (np.ndarray) – y coordinates of all mesh nodes.

  • cells (np.ndarray) – Cell connectivity information.

  • potential (np.ndarray) – Potential values at all mesh nodes.

  • grad_x (np.ndarray) – x component of the gradient at all mesh nodes.

  • grad_y (np.ndarray) – y component of the gradient at all mesh nodes.

  • midpoints_plate (np.ndarray) – Midpoints of the facets of the upper plate boundary.

  • normal_derivatives_plate (np.ndarray) – Normal derivative values at the upper plate boundary midpoints.

  • normal_vectors_plate (np.ndarray) – Normal vectors at the upper plate boundary midpoints.

Note

We return the midpoints of the facets of the upper plate boundary since the gradient is constant on each cell (we chose DG0).

data.fom.solvensave(mesh, data_folder='test')[source]¶

Description

Full order model that solves the PDE and saves the output in an .h5 file.

Parameters:

  • mesh (str) – path to the mesh file.

  • data_folder (str) – path to the data folder.

Return type:

None

data.generate¶

Script to generate meshes, run simulations, and save results based on geometry parameters.

Example usage:

python -m data.generate --folder "test/test1" --data_file "test/test1.csv" --geometry_input "geometries/cantilever1.geo" --workers 2

There are several optional arguments to customize the behavior:

  • --folder: Path to the data folder (default: “test”).

  • --keep_old_mesh: If set, the old meshes folder will not be emptied before generating new meshes.

  • --keep_old_results: If set, the old results folder will not be emptied before generating new results.

  • --data_file: Path to the data file containing geometry parameter specifications (default: “test.csv”).

  • --parameters_file_name: Name of the parameters file to save the generated parameters (default: “parameters.csv”).

  • --geometry_input: Path to the input geometry file (default: “geometry.geo”).

  • --plot_number: Number of the solution to plot (default: 1).

  • --workers: Number of worker processes to use for parallel mesh generation (default: 1).

data.generate.main()[source]¶

data.geometry¶

data.geometry._generate_single_geometry(j, param, geometry_input, names, data_folder)[source]¶

Description

Generate a single geometry and return the CSV row string.

Parameters:

  • j (int) – Geometry index.

  • param (tuple) – Tuple of parameter values for the geometry.

  • geometry_input (str) – Path to the input geometry file.

  • names (list) – List of quantity names.

  • data_folder (str) – Path to the data folder.

Return type:

str

Returns:

CSV row string representing the geometry parameters.

data.geometry._modify_quantity(input_path, output_path, name, quantity, value)[source]¶

Description

Modify the geometry file to change the distance between the plates.

Parameters:

  • input_path (str) – Path to the geometry file (e.g., geometry.geo).

  • output_path (str) – Path to save the modified geometry file (e.g., ./).

  • name (str) – Name for the new geometry file (e.g., test).

  • quantity (str) – Quantity to modify (e.g., ‘distance’, ‘overetch’, ‘coeff(1)’, etc.).

  • value (float) – New quantity value to set (e.g., 2.0).

Returns:

None

data.geometry._setup_data(parameters_head, parameters_file_name, ignore_data=False, data_folder='test')[source]¶

Description

This function resets the data folder by either deleting all its contents or only cleaning the “geo” subfolder, based on the ignore_data flag. It also ensures the creation of necessary subfolders (i.e. “geo”, “msh”, “results”) and initializes the parameters CSV file, containing the geometric parameters of each geometry, with the provided header.

Parameters:

  • parameters_head (str) – Header line for the parameters CSV file.

  • parameters_file_name (str) – Name of the parameters CSV file.

  • ignore_data (bool) – Whether to ignore existing other data present in data_folder.

  • data_folder (str) – Path to the data folder to reset.

Return type:

None

Returns:

None

Note

In any case, this function ensures the necessary subfolders and parameters file are set up.

data.geometry.generate_geometries(names, ranges, num_points, geometry_input, data_folder='test', parameters_file_name='parameters.csv', ignore_data=False, max_workers=1)[source]¶

Description

Generate geometries by modifying the list of quantities over specified ranges. This function creates a series of geometry files with different parameters.

Parameters:

  • names (list[str]) – List of the names, that appear in the geometry file of the quantities.

  • ranges (list[tuple]) – List of ranges for each quantity.

  • num_points (list[int]) – List of number of points to generate within the specified ranges for each quantity.

  • geometry_input (str) – Path to the input geometry file.

  • data_folder (str) – Path to the data folder.

  • parameters_file_name (str) – Name of the parameters file to save the generated parameters.

  • ignore_data (bool) – Whether to ignore existing other data present in data_folder.

  • max_workers (int) – Maximum number of worker processes to use for parallel geometry generation.

Returns:

None

Note

For example you may want to set this equal to TRUE if you have more data in that folder, or already computed solutions, and for some reason you want to generate the geomteries in that folder avoid touching every file except the “geo” subfolder the parameters file.

Note

As output you get a series of geometry files in data_folder/geo and a parameters.csv file in data_folder.

data.geometry.read_data_file(file_path='test.csv')[source]¶

Description

Read a data file and extract variable metadata.

Parameters:

file_path (str) – Path to the data file.

Return type:

tuple

Returns:

  • names (list) – Variable names

  • ranges (list[tuple]) – Value ranges for each variable

  • num_points (list) – Number of points per variable

Raises:

FileNotFoundError – If the specified data file does not exist.

data.plot¶

data.plot._cells_plot(x, y, cells, sol, title='Title', xlabel='x', ylabel='y', colorbar_label='Quantity', cmap='RdBu_r', sharp_color_range=None, outside_sharpness=50, plot_triangulation=True, postpone_show=False)[source]¶

Description

It plots the provided solution over the domain using cell-based data.

Parameters:

  • x (ndarray) – x coordinates of the vertices.

  • y (ndarray) – y coordinates of the vertices.

  • cells (ndarray) – Connectivity of the mesh cells.

  • sol (ndarray) – Quantity defined per cell to be plotted.

  • title (str) – Title of the plot.

  • xlabel (str) – Label for the x-axis.

  • ylabel (str) – Label for the y-axis.

  • colorbar_label (str) – Label for the color bar.

  • cmap (str) – Colormap to use for plotting.

  • sharp_color_range (Optional[tuple]) – Optional range to create sharp color transitions.

  • outside_sharpness (int) – Number of color levels outside the sharp color range.

  • plot_triangulation (bool) – Whether to overlay the mesh triangulation.

  • postpone_show (bool) – Whether to postpone the plt.show() call.

Return type:

None

data.plot._vertices_plot(x, y, cells, sol, title='Title', xlabel='x', ylabel='y', colorbar_label='Quantity', cmap='RdBu_r', sharp_color_range=None, outside_sharpness=50, plot_triangulation=True, postpone_show=False)[source]¶

Description

It plots the specified solution over the domain using vertex-based data.

Parameters:

  • x (ndarray) – x coordinates of the vertices.

  • y (ndarray) – y coordinates of the vertices.

  • cells (ndarray) – Connectivity of the mesh cells.

  • sol (ndarray) – Quantity defined per vertex to be plotted.

  • title (str) – Title of the plot.

  • xlabel (str) – Label for the x-axis.

  • ylabel (str) – Label for the y-axis.

  • colorbar_label (str) – Label for the color bar.

  • cmap (str) – Colormap to use for plotting.

  • sharp_color_range (Optional[tuple]) – Optional range to create sharp color transitions.

  • outside_sharpness (int) – Number of color levels outside the sharp color range.

  • plot_triangulation (bool) – Whether to overlay the mesh triangulation.

  • postpone_show (bool) – Whether to postpone the plt.show() call.

Return type:

None

data.plot._zoom_around(ax, x0, y0, zoom)[source]¶

Description

It zooms the given axes around the specified center point.

Parameters:

  • ax (Axes) – The axes object to apply the zoom on.

  • x0 (float) – x coordinate of the zoom center.

  • y0 (float) – y coordinate of the zoom center.

  • zoom (float) – Zoom factor.

Return type:

None

data.plot.plot(x, y, cells, sol, title='Title', xlabel='x', ylabel='y', colorbar_label='Quantity', cmap='RdBu_r', sharp_color_range=None, outside_sharpness=50, plot_triangulation=True, postpone_show=False)[source]¶

Description

It plots the provided solution over the domain.

Parameters:

  • x (ndarray) – x coordinates of the vertices.

  • y (ndarray) – y coordinates of the vertices.

  • cells (ndarray) – Connectivity of the mesh cells.

  • sol (ndarray) – Quantity defined per vertex or per cell to be plotted.

  • title (str) – Title of the plot.

  • xlabel (str) – Label for the x-axis.

  • ylabel (str) – Label for the y-axis.

  • colorbar_label (str) – Label for the color bar.

  • cmap (str) – Colormap to use for plotting.

  • sharp_color_range (Optional[tuple]) – Optional range to create sharp color transitions.

  • outside_sharpness (int) – Number of color levels outside the sharp color range.

  • plot_triangulation (bool) – Whether to overlay the mesh triangulation.

  • postpone_show (bool) – Whether to postpone the plt.show() call.

Return type:

None

Note

If you set the solution to None you can plot only the domain.

data.plot.plot_domain(file, postpone_show=False, zoom=None, center_points=None)[source]¶

Description

It plots the domain and the mesh.

Parameters:

  • file (File) – h5py file object containing the solution data.

  • postpone_show – Whether to postpone the plt.show() call.

  • zoom (Optional[list[int]]) – List of zoom levels for different subplots.

  • center_points (Optional[list[tuple]]) – List of center points \((x_0, y_0)\) for each zoom level.

Return type:

None

data.plot.plot_grad(file, postpone_show=False, zoom=None, center_points=None, component='x')[source]¶

Description

It plots the x component of the gradient of the electrostatic potential.

Parameters:

  • file (File) – h5py file object containing the solution data.

  • postpone_show – Whether to postpone the plt.show() call.

  • zoom (Optional[list[int]]) – List of zoom levels for different subplots.

  • center_points (Optional[list[tuple]]) – List of center points \((x_0, y_0)\) for each zoom level.

  • component (str) – Component of the gradient to plot (“x” or “y”).

data.plot.plot_normal_derivative(file, postpone_show=False, pred=False, error=False, zoom=None, center_points=None)[source]¶

Description

It plots the normal derivative of the potential on the upper plate as arrows.

Parameters:

  • file – h5py file object containing the solution data.

  • postpone_show – Whether to postpone the plt.show() call.

  • pred – Whether to plot the predicted normal derivative.

  • error – Whether to plot the error in normal derivative prediction.

  • zoom (Optional[list[int]]) – List of zoom levels for different subplots.

  • center_points (Optional[list[tuple]]) – List of center points \((x_0, y_0)\) for each zoom level.

Note

If both pred and error are True, a ValueError is raised.

data.plot.plot_potential(file, postpone_show=False, zoom=None, center_points=None, pred=False, error=False, error_type='se')[source]¶

Description

It plots the electrostatic potential over the domain.

Parameters:

  • file (File) – h5py file object containing the solution data.

  • postpone_show – Whether to postpone the plt.show() call.

  • zoom (Optional[list[int]]) – List of zoom levels for different subplots.

  • center_points (Optional[list[tuple]]) – List of center points \((x_0, y_0)\) for each zoom level.

  • pred (bool) – Whether to plot the predicted potential.

  • error (bool) – Whether to plot the error in potential prediction.

  • error_type (str) – Type of error to plot (“se” for squared error, “ae” for absolute error).

Return type:

None

data.plot.summary_plot(file)[source]¶

Description

It creates a summary plot with all relevant plots.

Parameters:

file (File) – h5py file object containing the solution data.

Return type:

None

data.remove_msh¶

Script to remove all .msh files from a specified data folder. Example of usage:

python -m data.remove_msh --folder <data_folder_path>
data.remove_msh.main()[source]¶

data.test¶

data.test.test(names, ranges, num_points, geometry_input, parameters_file_name='parameters.csv', data_folder='test', plot_number=None, empty_old_mesh=True, empty_old_results=True, workers=1)[source]¶

Description

Test function to generate geometries, meshes, and datasets, and optionally plot a specific solution. It orchestrates the entire process by calling the relevant functions from other modules.

Parameters:

  • names (list[str]) – List of the names, that appear in the geometry file of the quantities.

  • ranges (list[tuple]) – List of ranges for each quantity.

  • num_points (list[int]) – List of number of points to generate within the specified ranges for each quantity.

  • geometry_input (str) – Path to the input geometry file.

  • parameters_file_name (str) – name of the parameters file to save the generated parameters.

  • data_folder (str) – path to the data folder.

  • plot_number (Optional[int]) – number of the solution to plot.

  • empty_old_mesh (bool) – whether to empty the old meshes folder before generating new meshes.

  • empty_old_results (bool) – whether to empty the old results folder before generating new results.

Return type:

None

Note

If plot_number is None, no plots are generated.

Note

The geometry generation is skipped if one of the empty_old_mesh or empty_old_results is False.
